The Janssen (J&J) vaccine manufactured at a Emergent Biosolutions plant will fall short of the originally planned amount by 60mn doses that will not receive clearance by the FDA and will be eliminated from deliveries worldwide. The German Federal Ministry for Health so far expected 10.1mn doses of the single-shot Janssen vaccine in the second quarter of 2021 (April, May, June)), but received only 1.7mn of these doses and only 1.2mn doses have yet been administered. It is unclear whether the Emergent incident will cause a total collapse of deliveries in Q2 2021 and beyond, but it already means that those 8.4mn doses outstanding will have to be replaced by about 17mn doses of any other (two-shot-regimen) vaccine, and potentially delays the federal German vaccination campaign by ONE MONTH on average (Berlin being in the mid field).

Even though the Delta (B.1.617.2) variant is still rare in Germany and accounts for only 2% to 3% of all positive tests under surveillance, it has been steadily growing over the past few weeks and, unlike the Beta (B.1.351) and Gamma (P.1) variants, which have almost disappeared now, is likely to stay and have a growing share. Given its likely higher transmissibility (+60% versus Alpha (B.1.1.7)) and signs of higher likelihood of a severe illness and deadly outcome, and given the initial experience with the Alpha variant in the winter 2020/21, public administrations have raised the alarms somewhat.

Vaccine rollout and the museum plans an opening in July (https://www.zeit.de/news/2021-05/25/humboldt-forum-oeffnet-mitte-juli-weiter-maengel-in-technik).
Humboldt Forum officially says it plans to open in mid-July. The outdoor spaces, store and cafe will open in the second week of June.

Made a call to the museums hotline - they confirmed that Mid July - plus minus some days is feasable. Many sources pointing to the same conclusion let me believe opening is finally around the corner - plus Covid-19 cases dropping drastically even in Berlin plus there are federal elections in Germany - you need to keep the masses entertained. High conviction.

According to the links posted by @SE_Meyer , the opening of the Humboldt Forum is mostly about structural errors and missing safety measures in the machine rooms. However, it is also said that the errors can be corrected so that a partial opening should be possible by mid of june.

A final report due 15 June will show whether an opening in mid-July is still feasible amid massive failiure of technical equipment and elements of construction that could possibly pose a threat to the building, its visitors and the stored artworks. I'm thrilled what else will be uncovered in the coming days.
slightly up on the articles provided by @Columbus
The first article speaks of a partial opening in the spring, the second of the summer. Sounds like mid to late June, early July, but nothing is official yet:
Several of Berlin's museums are announced to start selling tickets and allow limited visitor numbers back in from next week. However, the Humboldt Forum is apparently not among them.

"Kultureinrichtungen: Museen, Theater, Kinos und Konzerthäuser

Incidence per week*100k people is unexpectedly falling and now lingering around 100 in Berlin which is the crucial mark according to the federal emergency brake to have ANY indoor facility plans. Due to public holidays in May (Ascension Day/fathers' day and Pentecost), most laender are concerned with hospitality outdoor business reopening, besides relaxing restrictions in access to childcare. No mentioning of culture at this point, apart from traditional open-air cinemas, who plan to operate this summer again.
vaccination is picking up in Europe, lagging four weeks to the US, so, all things equal by August most places will have some kind of public access.

Latest numbers indicate vaccination programs are ramping up and more than half the population should be vaccinated by Aug 1. While this is lower than previously expected it may still prove enough to test open cultural institutions over the summer. I'm revising my estimate down by 15% but still think odds are better than not that it will open with restrictions.
Vaccination rates in Germany have begun a dramatic increase, now that EU supply has improved. There may be enough inoculated by July that things will open sooner.

Given the recent legislation to permit the federal government to issue regulations based on infection rates, and the introduction of restrictions due to current conditions, I am lowering my forecast by half. Vaccinations are continuing a pace at a rate of about 500K/day which is good but not great. The vaccine supply is about to dramatically increase in the EU, it depends on how quickly the medical system can pivot to increase the daily rate. If the vaccination rate can be increased by 50% in May, then the chances of opening to the public may improve.

The German parliament is currently discussing the federal emergency brake mechanism ("Bundesnotbremse") and will likely vote to accept it later today against the votes of AfD, Die Linke MP's. The current version of the law, which has been fast-tracked amid a surge of infections in April, currently contains no exception for people fully vaccinate with respect to applicability. However, for certain situations being fully vaccinated may lead to an exemption from testing obligations.
Berlin is again in lockdown, the vaccination rhythm is slow

By AUG 1 already a lot og peple will be vacinated, plus tests are available thus i am sure that within July, there will be the possibility to visit, at least with test and or vaccinated visitors will be possible.

If they do, I´ll be there asap (and their newsletter will tell me, when it will be the case). At least half of the population will be inoculated by then: we´re at 19.8% with first shots already, and it will further speed up.
By August 1st the covid situation will not be good enough in Germany (not enough vaccines in particular)

They are only finishing up the last pieces and redoing the curating process for an exhibition with colonial-era statues from Benin. With vaccination rates getting better and better I don't see any reason it shouldn't open.

Many Berlin museums are open: https://www.smb.museum/en/information-covid19/ There will be a lot more vaccination in Germany in the next few weeks than before because more is finally being delivered. There is a good chance that the Humboldt Forum will be open for small crowds before August.

The federal emergency brake mechanism ("Bundesnotbremse") is being discussed today with MPs after being concluded by the cabinet on 15 April 2021. If MPs agree, representatives of the laender will be involved in the process, even though their vote is not necessary for putting legislation into force. The law will regulate the right to implement overnight curfews in unison for the first time in Germany, and it also takes some of the responsibilities from the governments and parliaments of the laender into the hands of federals, e.g. the determination of how and when to end phases of reopening in times of rising cases.
Germany is struggling with policy to limit Covid-19 infections, at this time a no-go. However, there are 60 days where something might happen, e.g. June and July.

Four of the stakeholders that curate spaces in the Humboldt Forum (two museums of the public foundation Stiftung Preußischer Kulturbesitz, the land Berlin (Stadtmuseum) and the Humboldt university) currently have consultations about a potential future opening date. https://www.berlin.de/ausstellungen/nachrichten/6466235-3041403-humboldt-forum-sucht-datum-fuer-echte-er.html

With Covid variants on the rise, I think it may be delayed

Given the details "The Humboldt Forum opening to the public with restrictions, such as requiring proof of COVID-19 vaccination or setting occupancy limits, would count.", I'm learning towards that it will happen. Either strong restrictions, or vaccination proof.
Merkel's promising everyone by September 21st. Production is ramping up. They are already talking about vaccine passports, which presumably would resolve this question as Yes.
Germany advancing of vaccination is low, but they can ask for COVID test instead of vaccination card. They can open to the public with restrictions.
Technology makes them happy.

Cultural institutions are planned to open when the incidence rate is below 50/100k, a week ago it sat at 136, more than doubling in a month, which was cause for increased restrictions until April 18. Roughly 11% have received their first vaccine dose with 40% of those having 2. By July 1 the EU is targeting over 40% of the population being vaccinated, which is likely enough to open the busy tourist season, especially with vaccine passports expected to be in use by mid-June (which again, is to support the tourist season). There will undoubtedly be restrictions on entry but it seems the odds are better than not it will open by August, likely a soft launch in conjunction with the passports in late June.

By mid July already there will be most high risk groups be vaccined, also testing for freedom will be a strategy more widely used thus eg it is very likely that all people with fresh test results and people with have been twice vaccined will have free access, general audience with Fsp2 Masks.

This question requires a clarification concerning what constitutes ‘opening’. The Humboldt Forum opening to the public with restrictions, such as requiring proof of COVID-19 vaccination or setting occupancy limits, would count.
Not until 2022
Following the excellent explanation offered by @SE_Meyer, and the current state of the pandemic and the lackluster vaccination campaign I'll say NO until either of those situations improve.

I assume them opening to vaccinated participants.

Cases are currently rising but I would guess Germany will have most of the population who wants a vaccine vaccinated by late summer and that cases will be much lower than now. I haven't done much research at the moment but this seems likely.
